moves.1. e4: She always used this move as White. We tried many counters, none of them worked.
moves.1... c6: J. B. had never played this, but he'd read in a book it was a good move, so he decided to try it.
moves.2. d4: Miss L. of course formed an ideal center.
moves.2... d5: This was as much of the book as J. B. remembered. We weren't professionals and didn't try to memorize the first 10 moves of every opening variation.
moves.3. Nc3: The game starts here, with the first actual piece being developed.
moves.3... dxe4: J. B. wanted to dissipate Miss L.'s center quickly.
moves.4. Nxe4: Miss L. now centralizes her Knight and regains the Pawn.
moves.4... Nd7: J. B. decides to get his pieces out as well.
moves.5. Qe2: Miss L. prepares for castling Q-side. But J. B. didn't see the tactical fine point this move also holds.
moves.5... Ngf6: J. B. tries to continue his development. However, it was necessary to play 5... P-K3 to prevent...
moves.6. Nd6#: ...this! The game ends with a lightning-bolt move.
